Article.ArticleTitle: Human-health impacts of controlling secondary air pollution precursors.

AbstractText: Exposure to ozone and fine particle (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) air pollution results in premature death. These pollutants are predominantly secondary in nature and can form from nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>X</sub>), sulfur oxides (SO<sub>X</sub>), and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Predicted health benefits for emission reduction scenarios often incompletely account for VOCs as precursors as well as the secondary organic aerosol (SOA) component of PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Here, we show that anthropogenic VOC emission reductions are more than twice as effective as equivalent fractional reductions of SO<sub>X</sub> or NO<sub>X</sub> at reducing air pollution-associated cardiorespiratory mortality in the United States. A 25% reduction in anthropogenic VOC emissions from 2016 levels is predicted to avoid 13,000 premature deaths per year, and most (85%) of the VOC-reduction benefits result from reduced SOA with the remainder from ozone. While NO<sub>X</sub> (-5.7 ± 0.2 % yr<sup>-1</sup>) and SO<sub>X</sub> (-12 ± 1 % yr<sup>-1</sup>) emissions have declined precipitously across the U.S. since 2002, anthropogenic VOC emissions (-1.8 ± 0.3 % yr<sup>-1</sup>) and concentrations of non-methane organic carbon (-2.4 ± 1.0 % yr<sup>-1</sup>) have changed less. This work indicates preferentially controlling VOCs could yield significant benefits to human health.
